James VI and I, born James Stuart, was King of Scotland (as James VI) from 1567 and King of England and Ireland (as James I) from 1603 until his death in 1625. He ruled two separate sovereign states, Scotland and England, each with its own parliament, judiciary, and laws. He advocated for a single parliament for both countries. During his reign in England, he faced significant challenges with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack, born on 26 December 1970, is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in various television series and films. She was part of the original cast of the soap opera "Shortland Street" and is recognized for her performances as Ephiny in "Xena: Warrior Princess," Cynthia Ross in "The Cult," and Shota in "Legend of the Seeker." Her film work includes "Separation City" (2009) and the Australian series "Rake." She also portrayed Kate Leigh in "Underbelly: Razor" and notably played Bea Smith in the prison drama "Wentworth" from 2012 until 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer. He is particularly recognized for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor known for starring in several comedy films, including "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," "Joe Dirt," "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," "Grown Ups," and "Grown Ups 2." "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser" is a 2015 comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

The album "Artpop" received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 with 258,000 copies sold in the first week, making it Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the U.S. It sold 757,000 copies in total and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, "Stadium Arcadium," in 2006. He left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister and implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is widely regarded as one of the most influential British politicians, though her legacy remains controversial.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Besides his music career, he is known for his writing, having contributed weekly columns on various topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has a diverse career that includes acting roles, as well as narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the third largest city and metropolitan area in the country, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in the city center and between 1.7 to 2.5 million in the metropolitan area. The autonomous community itself is also named Valencia.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in a television series.
The television series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, which was confirmed to be the final season on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It combines knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Key applications include voice user interfaces (like voice dialing and call routing), appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. The field has seen significant advancements, particularly with the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (1952-2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970, initially known as the Golden State Comic Book Convention, and served as its chairman. The event was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
The passage discusses "Fist of Legend," which is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury." The original film featured Bruce Lee as the lead character.

In the golf tournament, France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl both finished at 16 under par. McIlroy shot a 67, moving to 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, had an eagle on the 12th hole. Despite an ankle injury, he is pursuing his third Race to Dubai title, currently leading Danny Willett by 271,214 points. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland are in fifth and seventh places, respectively.

**Concise Summary:**

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of al-Wefaq, discusses the political situation in Bahrain with the BBC:

- **National Dialogue:** Salman stresses the need for concrete solutions and a representative from the royal family for meaningful dialogue.
- **Government Divisions:** Hardliners, led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, oppose dialogue, fearing it will encourage more opposition demands.
- **Crown Prince Salman:** Seen as a reformist, he had previously agreed to a seven-point plan with the opposition, but the dialogue was halted by the arrival of GCC troops.
- **International Pressure:** Salman hopes the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, will push harder for human rights and democracy. He criticizes the UK for not publicly pressuring Bahrain to reform.
- **Opposition Stance:** Al-Wefaq will continue to call for peaceful demonstrations and demands the release of 13 opposition leaders and activists to ensure the success of any dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a several-month illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including notable recordings like the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a highly acclaimed version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and academic roles at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. He was remembered for his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music. His funeral was private, with a memorial service planned for a later date.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure from nine years prior. Only one case from 2015-16 remained unresolved. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. About 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson acknowledged the decline in homicides but emphasized the need for continued efforts to combat violent crime and address alcohol misuse. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker welcomed the trend but cautioned against complacency, noting increases in sexual crime and violent crime categories like attempted murder and serious assault.

The passage discusses a football match where Bournemouth (referred to as "The Cherries") lost 2-1 to Sunderland. Key points include:

- Sunderland scored two goals, one by Victor Anichebe and another a penalty by Jermain Defoe.
- Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's only goal, their first in three games.
- Bournemouth had numerous chances to score but failed to convert them into goals.
- Sunderland played with 10 men for part of the game after Steven Pienaar's dismissal.
- Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe acknowledged his team's missed chances and emphasized the importance of moving forward.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Australian Policy**: Australia stops migrant boats and detains migrants in offshore processing camps, a policy criticized as "brutal" and "inhumane" by the New York Times.
- **Mr. Abbott's Stance**: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott argues that stopping boats is the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea.
- **Controversial Comments**: Abbott compared the Islamic State to the Nazis, angering Australian Jewish groups who argued that the comparison was inappropriate.
- **Abbott's Response**: Abbott stood by his comments but said he was not "ranking evil."

The passage discusses the escalating conflict in Aleppo, Syria. Key points include:

- The U.S. has suspended talks with Russia due to Russia's and Syria's intensified attacks on civilians and infrastructure in Aleppo.
- The main trauma hospital in rebel-held eastern Aleppo was hit in an air strike for the third time in a week.
- Hundreds of people, including children, have died since the offensive began, with 250,000 people trapped in eastern Aleppo.
- The U.S. accused Russia and Syria of targeting critical infrastructure and hindering humanitarian aid.
- Russia denied involvement in the aid convoy strike and blamed the U.S. for not fulfilling agreements to improve humanitarian conditions.
- The U.S. withdrew personnel dispatched for a potential joint implementation center with Russia but will continue talks on counter-terrorism operations to avoid clashes.

The passage discusses a report by the think tank Policy Exchange, which proposes selling high-value vacant social homes to raise £4.5bn a year. This money could be used to build 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes, potentially creating the largest social house building program since the 1970s. The think tank argues that this would reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000 people. However, Labour and other critics argue that this policy would drive out low-income families from affluent areas and create segregated communities. The government's official stance is that councils can choose to implement this policy to use their social housing stock more efficiently.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died last week. He had recently been treated for asthma and later developed a rash, which led to a measles diagnosis. Swansea is currently experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases. An inquest will be held to determine the cause of death, as measles has not been confirmed as the main cause. Since November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for measles. Colfer-Williams' family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close family members have it.

Vincent Hudson, a 54-year-old man from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense involving a boy under 16. The alleged incident occurred in 2001 and was reported to Cumbria Police. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The passage describes a National League football match between Gateshead and Guiseley. Key points include:

- Gateshead, managed by Neil Aspin, had a nine-match unbeaten streak, while Guiseley, managed by Adam Lockwood, were unbeaten in five.
- Guiseley scored first in the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor.
- Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wesley York.
- The match ended in a 1-1 draw.
- Several substitutions and a yellow card were issued during the match.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of a football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale. The project, approved by Bristol City Council in November, is set to begin in May if no judicial review is filed within six weeks of signing the section 106 agreement. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the start of work at a shareholder meeting.

**Summary:**

- **Event**: Cuadrilla, a fracking company, suspended drilling operations after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake, the second in two months.
- **Location**: The tremors occurred near Poulton-le-Fylde, Lancashire, UK.
- **Fracking**: The process involves using hydraulic pressure or explosions to release gas from shale rocks.
- **Response**: Cuadrilla will analyze data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding to resume operations.
- **Controversy**: Fracking is controversial due to environmental concerns, but the UK's energy select committee supports it with proper regulation.
- **Earthquakes**: Two small earthquakes have occurred since fracking began in Lancashire in March. The BGS is monitoring the situation.
- **BGS Findings**: The earthquakes are likely linked to the fracking process, with similar locations and mechanisms.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, giving the impression he was collecting funds for the charity. He was cleared of two other counts. Carpenter argued that he was merely busking and that the banner was a tribute to the victims. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers (QPR) 3-0 in a Championship match. Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence scored for Ipswich. QPR's Alex Smithies had a costly error leading to Varney's goal. Ipswich moved up to 14th place, while QPR dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised Luke Varney's performance, and QPR boss Ian Holloway criticized his team's mental toughness and defense. Ipswich had several scoring chances and could have won by a larger margin.

Wells, a 23-year-old player, had a notable performance in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about his club's direction, highlighting the elite performance environment created by the coaches, which motivates the team members.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams led the team, with the front row and front five making over 70 tackles. In their upcoming eight games, the Reds will face seven teams ranked below them and the league leaders, Old Elthamians. Coach Churcher acknowledges room for improvement but praises the team's emotional and determined performance against Chinnor, emphasizing the need to build on their recent success.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul, also known as Nazu, is accused of raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town. He was arrested in Kolkata, marking the sixth arrest in the case. Eight suspects are identified, with two still untraced. The incident sparked outrage and protests across India. The attack occurred on March 14, during which money was stolen and the convent school was ransacked.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. The video explains factors influencing changes in consumer purchasing habits in the UK, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also explores shifts in ownership and ranking of major UK brands. The video is best viewed in full screen and has a non-interactive alternative with additional information available through provided links.

Two incidents of fraud occurred in Scotland, involving scammers impersonating BT employees. In the first incident, on September 15, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked. A week later, a woman in Stranraer lost money after a caller, claiming to be from BT technical support, gained remote access to her computer. Police advise people to be cautious of cold calls requesting remote computer access and to never share banking details over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old former player and current Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, a third-placed Championship rugby side. He will coach their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone's chairman, Mark Campbell, praised Duffy's coaching abilities and his work at Swinton Lions, where he was previously employed. Duffy's former assistant, Stuart Littler, has taken over his role at Swinton.

The Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. An injured rider with head injuries and hypothermia from lying unconscious on wet sand was treated at the scene and then transported to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales by helicopter.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate a radio frequency for a global flight tracking system using satellites. This decision was made to improve upon the current ground-based radar system, which was highlighted as inadequate after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014. The new system will use automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions to enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) are involved in implementing this change, with ICAO setting a deadline of November 2016 for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez, who went missing at age five, has been found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez was arrested in Ohio and is charged with tampering with records. The FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed Julian's identity after receiving a tip during his college application process. Julian's mother has been notified. Bobby Hernandez is held at the Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had previously suspected his involvement in Julian's disappearance.

On March 2, a fire at a site operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited and managed by Asset and Land Group in Duncan Street caused train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended the company from accepting waste and later revoked their environmental permit, effective August 7, unless appealed. The company must remove all waste from the site. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which had visited the site nine times in the past year, noted that the operators were broadly compliant with fire safety laws but had raised concerns about potential fire impacts. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia in response to the situation in Ukraine, particularly in the Crimea region where pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill aims to simplify the process for a territory to join the Russian Federation, requiring only a referendum or a plea from local leaders, especially in cases where a neighboring state is disintegrating. The second bill expedites the issuance of Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing requirements for state tax, previous residence, financial means, and renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship. This bill is framed as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians. Additionally, Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea, and Russia has previously intervened in Georgia's breakaway regions.

**Concise Summary:**

McLaren, a historically successful Formula 1 team with 182 wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a slump. Their best hope for the current season is to finish in the fourth row of the grid and secure some points. The team's decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now they face problems with their Honda power-unit. Despite this, McLaren has two world champions in their lineup, including Fernando Alonso. The team's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with notable successes in the 1980s and 1990s. Team principal Ron Dennis believes that McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again, but the team's current performance relies heavily on belief and future prospects.

Thomas Baker, 44, was found injured and later died after being shot at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on January 27. He was shot while getting into his car outside Phoenix Gym. Three men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in custody. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo and appealing for witnesses captured on CCTV to come forward.

The passage discusses ways to enjoy Christmas online, focusing on spiritual and religious activities. It highlights five main points:

1. **Everyday Church Online**: A virtual church that streams services and allows global participants to chat during sermons. This year, they have a Star Wars-themed Christmas service called "The Hope Awakens."

2. **Guardians of Ancora**: A free fantasy game for children aged 8-11, developed by Scripture Union, where players rediscover Bible stories to bring light to a dark world. Special Christmas content includes quests about the birth of Jesus.

3. **Viral Nativity Videos**: Creative nativity stories told through social media updates and changing eras, aiming to spread the Christmas message in modern ways.

4. **Manga Messiah**: A company that translates Bible stories into Manga format, recently launched in app and e-book forms, with a focus on reaching diverse audiences, including refugees.

5. **Social Media Outreach**: Churches and Christian groups use platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to share spiritual thoughts and connect with communities, especially during Christmas.

The passage discusses an eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale regarding a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land. Key points include:

- **Proposal**: 250 hectares of common land to be taken over, with 320 hectares of replacement land offered by backers, including Blaenau Gwent council.
- **Conflicting Views**: Experts have differing opinions on the potential damage to habitats and plant life.
- **Natural Resources Wales**: Acknowledges difficulty in concluding equal value of replacement land but does not oppose the development overall.
- **Ecology Report**: Developers claim a "net gain" in biodiversity with plans to enhance nearby habitats, which the Gwent Wildlife Trust disputes.
- **Decision Process**: The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, with the final decision by Welsh government ministers.

On April 1, 2017, Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 men suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, stating that detainees were tortured. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations. Chechen clerics met on April 3, issuing a resolution that was interpreted as a call for reprisals against the journalists. Novaya Gazeta urged Russian authorities to protect journalists. The paper's report included influential clerics and TV presenters among the detainees. The LGBT Network is helping victims flee and threatens to take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia does not act.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Organizations Involved:** Investing Solutions (letting agency) and Fresh Start Housing (charity) share the same building and were founded by Samir Patel.
- **Operation:** Investing Solutions finds properties for single homeless men (aged 35+) and receives housing benefit payments, passing most of the rent to private landlords but keeping a significant profit.
- **Criticism:** A homeless group and a charity criticize the relationship, citing poor housing conditions and profit-driven motives.
- **Funding:** Nearly half of Investing Solutions' income comes from Wandsworth Council, totaling over £2.1m in two years.
- **Impact:** Fresh Start Housing has housed 788 homeless people since its founding, with 222 housed in the last year.
- **Regulation:** Local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money and inspecting private sector housing.

In a recent basketball game, Great Britain (GB) faced the Netherlands. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 for GB. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the game but lost in the final 10 minutes. GB will next play in Hungary for their Eurobasket qualifying campaign. Prunty emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity throughout the qualifiers. The Netherlands won the game 71-60, with Worthy De Jong leading their scoring with 18 points. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, noting his strong third quarter.

Conor McGregor, a former five-weight world champion in MMA, submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to potentially use lighter gloves in his upcoming boxing match against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC will debate this request on August 16, as lighter gloves can increase punch impact but offer less hand protection. Mayweather had previously expressed his intention to use 8oz gloves, but had not submitted the necessary waiver at that time. The NAC prioritizes fighter safety and will decide on the glove size based on health considerations. McGregor, 29, will make his boxing debut against Mayweather, 40, in what could be the richest fight in history. The NAC approved the fight after reviewing McGregor's skills and background, including his performances against Nate Diaz. McGregor has been preparing with a boxing referee, Joe Cortez, who oversaw intense sparring sessions.

The passage discusses the decline of Fleet Street, once the hub of British journalism. Key points include:

- Fleet Street was home to most national newspapers and was a significant source of public information before the rise of television and social media.
- The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702.
- Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post, are among the last journalists to leave Fleet Street.
- The street was famous for its bars and pubs, where journalists socialized and sought stories.
- The decline of Fleet Street began in the 1980s when media companies moved to other locations, adopting new printing technologies.
- The passage also highlights the historical significance of Fleet Street and the end of an era in British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, the author of Harry Potter, has been facing abusive comments on Twitter due to her political views, particularly her donation to the campaign against Scottish independence. She has blocked some abusive users, including those she believes are SNP supporters, but has also engaged positively with other SNP supporters. Rowling has received both criticism and support on Twitter, with some users even suggesting her books should be burned. Despite the abuse, she has found that there are more decent people than not on the platform. The SNP won a significant number of seats in the recent UK election.

The passage discusses a study by the University of Edinburgh that found:

- Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and more likely to engage in violence than better-off children.
- Poorer young people are five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision and more likely to offend, even when other risk factors are considered.
- Extreme poverty increases the likelihood of being both a victim and perpetrator of crime.
- Boys are three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime than those from affluent households.
- The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 to understand changes in their behavior and lifestyles.
- Despite an overall fall in crime rates, the most deprived communities continue to experience the highest crime rates, with chronic health problems and unemployment being significant factors.
- The Scottish government acknowledges the findings and highlights initiatives to tackle poverty and inequalities.

On Sunday, Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway at the Marian estate in Kilkee. Robbie Walsh, from Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and was remanded in custody. Two other men arrested were released without charge. According to Det Sgt Padraig Frawley, Walsh and two others entered the estate around 01:00, looking for Mr. Haugh, and a fight ensued involving weapons. Mr. Haugh was stabbed and pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. A knife with blood on it was recovered at the scene. Walsh is to appear in court again on 14 August.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted about Tom Elliott, a UDR veteran and MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, suggesting Elliott had harassed and shot people during his UDR service. Elliott sued Flanagan for defamation. In the High Court, Flanagan admitted his tweet was untrue and agreed to apologize. The court is yet to decide on compensation, and Flanagan's insurance has refused to cover the costs. Elliott expressed disappointment in the delay but satisfaction with the outcome.

**Summary:**

- **Company:** Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874, employs over 230 staff.
- **Recent Changes:** Acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November 2022.
- **Product Launch:** New Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January, with better-than-expected sales.
- **Production Increase:** Boosted production from 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters per week to meet demand.
- **Markets:** Operates in Europe (9 countries) and internationally (USA, Canada, Mexico, Japan).
- **Growth:** Experiencing growth in both private label and own-brand sales.
- **Future Outlook:** Positive, with plans to continue success.

A 72-year-old lollipop lady, Sylvia Blackburn, was seriously injured when a VW Golf driven by Brian Wright, 55, failed to stop at a red light in Kempston last December. Wright admitted to hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright apologized in court, acknowledging that Blackburn was well-loved by the children she helped cross the road. The incident occurred as Blackburn was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the street. Wright claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and did not remember the traffic light color. The trial is ongoing.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Event:** NATO exercise "Dynamic Mongoose" involving 10 warships, helicopters, and underwater drones to track the German U-boat U33.
- **Context:** Response to increased Russian submarine activity in European waters, highlighting gaps in Britain's defenses, particularly the lack of maritime patrol aircraft.
- **Key Players:** U33 (acting as the enemy), USS Vicksburg (command ship), HMS Portland (Royal Navy frigate), and a French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft.
- **Concerns:** Russia's growing submarine fleet and technological advancements, Britain's vulnerability due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft.
- **Purpose:** To prepare NATO for anti-submarine warfare and address defense gaps in member nations.

The passage discusses the ongoing ethnic violence and potential genocide in South Sudan, which has led to a massive refugee crisis. Key points include:

- Over 340,000 people have fled South Sudan to Uganda since July 2016, with an average of 2,500 people fleeing daily.
- The violence is driven by ethnic tensions, primarily between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, with Equatorians also being targeted.
- Refugees report widespread killing, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines.
- Uganda has been accommodating refugees generously, but resources are becoming strained.
- The UN and aid agencies are working to support refugees, but the situation is dire and requires international attention.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old boxer, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on November 12 at York Hall. He turned professional in 2013 after a football career and has a record of eight wins and one draw. McKenzie is the son of former champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the planned replacement of Bridgwater Community Hospital, which is part of a £330m coalition investment for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and in need of replacement. The project, costing £33m, will be funded by the coalition, NHS Somerset, and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is planned to be built on land at Bowers Lane, with completion aimed for autumn 2014, pending planning permission. This replacement is part of a broader effort to modernize community hospitals in Somerset.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city center, while in or near his black Mercedes car. Police were called around 13:35 GMT and found the man with a chest wound. He was taken to Northern General Hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents identified the victim as a member of a family living nearby, who were gathering for a celebration when the shooting occurred. This incident is one of several recent shootings in Sheffield, with previous incidents occurring in different areas of the city.

The passage discusses three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukraine conflict:

1. **Ukrainian Cyber Troops**: Led by Yevhen Dokukin, they hack government servers, use DDoS attacks, disrupt rebel funding, and monitor CCTV systems. They claim to have exposed Russian military involvement in Ukraine.

2. **Cyber Berkut**: An anti-Western group aiming to disrupt Ukraine's military plans. They hack government websites, electronic billboards, and claim to have leaked sensitive documents, including those related to Malaysia Airlines flight MH17.

3. **Anonymous International (b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay)**: Known for leaking Kremlin documents, they also publish material related to Ukraine, such as emails from a key rebel commander and a letter from a Russian fighter.

The groups present themselves as independent activists, and their activities include hacking, data leaks, and disruptive cyber-attacks.

**Concise Summary:**

- Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran MSPs Duncan McNeil (Labour) and Alex Salmond (SNP) gave their farewell speeches before stepping down ahead of the 5 May election.
- **Duncan McNeil** warned Holyrood to improve its committee system and learn from Westminster to ensure accountability and scrutiny.
- **Alex Salmond**, former first minister, reiterated that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and welcomed the Scotland Bill's power transfer but insisted it fell short of referendum pledges. He humorously referenced the Chancellor's UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse.
- **Annabel Goldie** (Conservative) also bid farewell, joking about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering experiences from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care practices. The review is supported by Care Forum Wales, although they expressed disappointment that no care provider expert is included on the main advisory panel.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Company:** Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, Scotland
- **Financial Performance (Year ending June 2016):**
  - Pre-tax profit increased by £800,000 to £3.5m
  - Turnover decreased by £1m to just over £100m
- **Business Operations:**
  - Manufactures and supplies animal feeds for various sectors
  - Operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, catering to farming and rural communities
- **International Sales:** Grew in Europe and new markets
- **Outlook:** Cautious due to challenging times and Brexit uncertainty, but the board is confident in the group's robustness and positioning.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted. A man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as a murder and are seeking a 55-year-old man, Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), for questioning. McLoughlin is described as a white man, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair, and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Police have increased patrols in the area and are asking for the public's help in locating McLoughlin.

David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, spoke about global economic risks, noting a weakening baseline and a delicate juncture. This follows China's disappointing trade figures, with exports dropping by 25% year-over-year. The IMF is expected to lower its global growth forecast from 3.4% in its April update. This economic slowdown has significant implications for businesses relying on China's growth.

The council has made the Cowes ferry crossing free until July 2nd due to several issues since its launch on May 14th, including breakdowns, groundings, suspensions, and vehicle damage. The council has ordered an audit and is discussing compensation for local businesses affected by the loss of trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged teething problems but stated that many issues have been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook was closed until early evening for the investigation.

**Concise Summary:**

Matching Models, a London temp agency, faced criticism for job adverts that specified physical attributes like hair color and breast size. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners condemned these ads as unlawful and demeaning. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the ads, stating that looks are important to their clients. Employment lawyer James Lynas called the adverts "clearly unlawful" and potentially discriminatory against older women. The agency's clients include high-profile brands like MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods. The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various factors, including age, disability, and race.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot two students: 18-year-old Gautami, who was killed, and Sirisha, who was severely injured. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until April 12. The motive for the shooting is unclear. Gun crimes at schools in India are rare, despite strict gun control laws.

Glaad's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found:

- 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters.
- An increase in transgender characters from 7 to 16.
- Over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington from "Orange is the New Black" and Bea Smith from "Wentworth".
- A record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, driven by shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder".
- The study was based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series that were airing or had confirmed casting.
- Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, noted progress but emphasized that numbers are "only part of the story".

Conservative MP David Mackintosh for Northampton South announced he will not seek re-election amid controversy over a £10.25 million loan to Northampton Town FC, which is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Mackintosh, who was criticized for the loan when he was the council leader, denied any wrongdoing. Most of his local party's executive council had planned to oppose his candidacy.

In April, Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards as the teenager was leaving a party in Balch Springs, Texas. Oliver fired into a car full of teenagers, initially claiming the vehicle reversed aggressively towards him, but footage showed the car driving away. Oliver was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. He was fired from his job and is currently out on bail. The trial date has not been set. Jordan Edwards was described as an exemplary young man by his coach. If convicted, Oliver could face 5 to 99 years in prison and would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Melania Trump and Barron** will move to Washington after Barron finishes the school year, but no specific date has been given.
- **Criticism and Support**: Some criticize Melania Trump's decision not to move immediately, while others support her focus on Barron's education.
- **Historical Context**: Only two other First Ladies (Martha Washington and Anna Harrison) did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies.
- **First Lady's Role**: The role is ceremonial but has evolved to include supporting causes. Melania Trump has hinted at an interest in tackling cyber-bullying.
- **Family Life in the White House**: Previous first families have managed to maintain normalcy and privacy, with the White House adapting to their needs.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on October 27. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) ordered the investigation, and a report will be submitted to them upon completion.

The passage discusses a yellow wind warning issued for several counties in the UK, including Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. The warning predicts gusts up to 75mph, particularly to the west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction that could increase the impact. Disruptions to travel on roads and at sea are expected. Specifically, a tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road for clean-up work on Monday.

The Giants and Panthers played a hockey game where the Giants initially led, but the Panthers tied it up. In the second period, the Giants took a 2-1 lead, which was then equalized. The Giants scored two more goals, making it 4-2, before Nottingham scored one back. The teams will play again the following Saturday. Nottingham is currently leading the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Race Winner:** Nico Rosberg (Mercedes)
- **Podium Finishers:** Daniel Ricciardo (Red Bull) in 2nd, Sebastian Vettel (Ferrari) in 3rd.
- **Lewis Hamilton's Race:** Started from the back, suffered front wing damage, made five pit stops, finished in 11th place.
- **Key Incidents:** Multiple first-lap collisions, including Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen (Ferrari) and Hamilton and Felipe Nasr (Sauber). Safety car deployed on lap four.
- **Points Standings:** Hamilton now trails Rosberg by 36 points with 18 races remaining.
- **Notable Performances:** Ricciardo took the lead from Rosberg at the first corner but suffered a puncture, allowing Rosberg to win. Raikkonen recovered to 5th place after starting 10th.
- **Post-Race Controversy:** Vettel confronted Kvyat about a first-lap incident, with Kvyat defending his actions.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance the discussion of this topic in German football. He received widespread support from former teammates, football administrators, and public figures. Hitzlsperger's announcement is considered a significant moment in the fight against homophobia in German football. Despite progress, there are still challenges, as noted by former Germany captain Philipp Lahm's past controversial statements. The German Chancellor's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck also praised Hitzlsperger's courage, hoping it would encourage others and break down taboos.

Gary Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton & Hove Albion secure promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. With his current contract expiring, he hopes to sign a new deal to help the team stay in the top flight. Brighton has a four-point lead over Newcastle with two matches left, aiming to clinch the league title. Sidwell previously played for several Premier League clubs and believes he has earned another opportunity at the top level. He has made a significant impact this season, playing more games than expected and performing well.

The passage describes a football match between Blackpool and Colchester United that ended in a 1-1 draw. Key events include:

- Blackpool scored first with Jamille Matt converting a chance after 12 minutes.
- Colchester equalized from a corner through Kurtis Guthrie after 17 minutes.
- Both teams had chances to score, with notable saves by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe.
- Blackpool had a chance to win late in the game but missed.
- Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

A 29-year-old player, who made 37 appearances for Coventry City (the Sky Blues) last season during their relegation from League One, is set to potentially debut for Colchester United (the U's) in an upcoming EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. This player has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

PC Keith Palmer's murder in March 2017 outside the Houses of Parliament highlighted the need for a permanent memorial to honor fallen police officers. The UK Police Memorial Trust aims to build this memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, with a goal of raising £1.5 million. The memorial will commemorate over 1,400 officers and staff, recognizing their sacrifice over the past 250 years. It will feature a brass screen with personal memorials for the families of fallen officers. The UK government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million project, with completion expected by 2019.

Manchester United secured a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games remaining. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on upcoming matches, particularly the derby against Manchester City. United has won 25 out of their first 30 matches and aims to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record from 2005. Ferguson noted injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, and plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea. He also mentioned the availability of Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez, while Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley were rested. The match was described as a battle, with United's win attributed to determined defending and courage.

Google's executive chairman, Eric Schmidt, defended the company's tax payments in the UK, stating that they paid £10 million in corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, which was legally required. He argued that it is up to the government to change tax laws if they want companies to pay more. Schmidt also suggested that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs, not where products are consumed. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, and the EU agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Google has been criticized for minimizing its UK tax payments by routing sales through Ireland.

The NHS regulator, NHS Improvement, aims to reduce agency staff spending by £1bn by the end of the financial year, as the current £3.6bn expenditure is behind schedule. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates for all staff except senior managers. The goal is to decrease costs and reduce reliance on agency staff, who are more expensive due to additional agency fees and employer costs. While progress is "promising," the NHS is still short of its target, with agency spending down by only 10%. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of trust performances on agency spending and collect data on high-earning agency staff, noting instances of excessive quoting for doctors' rates. The regulator emphasizes the need for further reductions in agency staff spending.

The passage discusses the economic situation of Longford Town Centre in Ireland, which was once a symbol of prosperity but now represents the economic downturn. Key points include:

- Local traders, like Matt O'Brien, report a recent increase in business after years of decline.
- Political parties have differing views on how to stimulate the local economy, with Fianna Fáil criticizing the government's investment priorities.
- The government highlights the potential economic boost from a planned Center Parcs development.
- Traders suggest that free parking could attract more customers to the town centre.
- Overall, while there are signs of economic recovery, more is needed to fully revitalize the area.

The passage discusses a cricket tournament involving eight teams, each playing against each other twice. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs, with the final scheduled for May 29. Key statistics include leading run-scorers (Warner, Kohli, De Villiers), most sixes (Warner and De Villiers), highest individual score (De Kock), and most wickets (McClenaghan). Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The passage also lists the fixtures and results for the tournament, with matches scheduled from April 25 to May 29.

The passage discusses the issue of plastic carrier bag waste, which has increased by 200 million since 2013. Many of these bags are not recyclable and end up in landfills and rivers, harming the environment. Starting in October, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags to encourage reuse. This policy has already led to a decrease in bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges are in place. Campaigners hope this will reduce waste and benefit the environment.

The passage describes the impact of strong winds in Wales on a Friday during the festive season. Key points include:

- A school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, near Caernarfon.
- Hundreds of homes experienced power cuts.
- There were train delays and restrictions on major bridges.
- A yellow wind warning was in effect until midnight.
- The winds caused disruptions to ferry services, train services, and led to the closure of some National Trust properties.
- The winds eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to reunite with director Ryan Coogler for an upcoming film, though his role is unspecified. He is also eager to work with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently starring as Black Panther in "Captain America: Civil War." Jordan previously starred in the "Fantastic Four" reboot, and Nyong'o played a CGI character in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." "Black Panther" is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The passage discusses the planned restoration of Alexandra Palace's theatre and BBC studios, part of a larger east wing project costing £26.6m. The theatre, founded in 1875, aims to host various performances and screenings upon reopening in 2018, pending successful fundraising. Key contributors include the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m) and Haringey Council (£6.8m), with the trust aiming to raise the remaining £1m. The theatre retains original decor and machinery, originally designed for diverse entertainment. The east court will also be transformed into a public exhibition space.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has 61 caps for England, debuting in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, starting in 2004. He scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. Milner announced his retirement from international football, wishing success to the team and its supporters.

A family in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, escaped a house fire that destroyed their home and resulted in the deaths of their pets. Marcy Smith, her son David, and her daughter fled in their pajamas. David, who was awake and on FaceTime with his father, alerted the family to the fire. The fire started from a wood stove and the fire alarm did not go off. The community has supported the family by donating clothes and other items. Marcy Smith credits David with saving her and her daughter's lives.

The passage discusses a potential £200m offer for West Ham United by an energy drinks company. David Sullivan and David Gold purchased a majority stake in the club in 2010 for £105m, and together they own over 85% of the club. Since moving to the London Stadium, West Ham has been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan previously mentioned the possibility of selling a minority share to reduce debts but intends for the ownership to eventually pass to their children.

The passage describes the MTV Movie Awards, where various films and actors were honored. Key points include:

- The event was held in Los Angeles and featured fan-voted awards.
- "The Fault in Our Stars" won best movie, and Shailene Woodley won multiple awards, including best female performance.
- Bradley Cooper won best male performance for "American Sniper."
- Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for "22 Jump Street."
- Meryl Streep won best villain for "Into the Woods."
- Kevin Hart won the comedic genius award and dedicated it to his kids.
- Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by his "Avengers" co-stars.
- Clips from upcoming summer blockbusters were shown, including "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."

Smith, a 21-year-old Scottish Under-21 international, was loaned to St Mirren from Aberdeen in July. He has scored five goals this season and four goals in 89 appearances for Aberdeen. St Mirren manager Jack Ross praised Smith as a good player and a good fit for the team, providing another attacking option. St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, is set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

The passage discusses Northumberland County Council's plan to repair potholes and drainage systems. Key points include:

- The weather is now suitable for using Jetpatcher machines to fix potholes.
- The council aims to fill 145 potholes per day over the next four months.
- Additional staff will repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Incident**: In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework.
- **Exposure**: The workers were exposed for hours without proper personal protective equipment (PPE).
- **Response**: EnQuest and Wood Group conducted a joint investigation, took additional precautionary steps, and downmanned employees for medical assessments. EnQuest informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) about the incident, but it was not reportable under the current system.
- **Concerns**: Rigging supervisor Steve Innes raised concerns about the duty of care, the lack of proper PPE, and the potential long-term health effects. He also mentioned struggles in finding work since raising these concerns.
- **Union and HSE**: The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers and emphasized the need for transparency. The HSE was aware of the incident but did not investigate as it was not reportable.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore is returning a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India. The sculpture, purchased for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. The decision to return the artwork followed discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), after the ASI requested its return in May. The museum is also considering legal action against the dealer for fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in cities as far as Milan and Florence, with several aftershocks reported. There were no immediate injuries or damage reports, but phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. The earthquake was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" by INGV. Italy has a history of significant earthquakes, including a deadly one in L'Aquila in 2009, and another in the same area last May.

The passage discusses a man named Austin Grant from Sheffield who successfully grew a fruit in South Yorkshire's climate. Despite initial doubts, he was thrilled to see results, as the fruit, though not yet ripe, is still attached to the plant.

**Summary:**

* Rockstar has delayed the game's release to March 24, from the original date of January 27, to allow for additional testing and polishing.
* The delay is to ensure the game's quality and is in the best interest of fans.
* Good news includes:
	+ Online heists are coming to consoles before PC.
	+ PC version will have high graphical details, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor setups.
	+ Minimum PC specifications for the game have been published.
* Grand Theft Auto V, released in 2013, was the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in three days.

A 76-year-old artist named Simpson won the Â£25,000 prize at the John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)", which depicts a leper squint in medieval churches. The painting was described as "extraordinary" but "difficult to look at" by judge Ansel Krut. Simpson plans to use the prize money to buy art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The passage discusses coordinated attacks on the offices of two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, early on Thursday. Four masked assailants set fire to the Yeni Safak building and fired shots at both buildings, shattering windows and leaving spent bullet casings. No casualties were reported, and police are investigating the incidents. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. This is not the first time pro-government media outlets have been targeted, as last September, protesters attacked the offices of the daily Hurriyet.

The 24-year-old player, previously with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer starting January 1st. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. This signing marks Bignot's first for the Mariners.

Arsene Wenger, whose contract runs until the summer, has been mentioned as a potential candidate for the England national team job. Current interim manager Gareth Southgate, who took over from Sam Allardyce, has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove himself. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and competence. Additionally, Wenger announced that Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, despite interest from other clubs, and that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation, with the company cooperating fully.

The passage discusses a resolution to a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union had alleged that some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The dispute involved Seatruck, the operator of the vessels Hellier and Hildasay, and Serco Northlink, which contracts Seatruck to run the service. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap but Seatruck declined. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that will return the contracted services to Serco Northlink next month, ensuring all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink operates three ferries and two cargo boats on a route heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on May 14 after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell's mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57, with whom Dickie had been in a relationship. On May 7, after a confrontation at the park's bar, Mitchell and Dickie fought outside, leading to Dickie's death. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and both Mitchells admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police. They will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter, passed away in London at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Known for his hits like "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," and "Thriller" for Michael Jackson, as well as "Boogie Nights" for his band Heatwave, Temperton was nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile. Born in Cleethorpes, his songwriting was influenced by his father, who played radio in his crib. Temperton's career took off in the 1970s with Heatwave and later with Michael Jackson, contributing significantly to the success of "Off The Wall" and "Thriller." He won a Grammy and was nominated for two Oscars. Temperton's private funeral has taken place, and tributes have poured in from notable figures in the music industry.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. These "geoglyphs" were hidden by rainforest until recent deforestation revealed over 450 large geometrical structures. The purpose of these sites is unclear, but they may have been used as ritual gathering places rather than villages or defensive structures. The geoglyphs were likely built amidst tall vegetation, unlike other ritual sites. The research challenges the notion of the Amazon as a pristine ecosystem, suggesting humans cultivated a diverse range of plant species over 6,000 years, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. Some of Acre's current biodiversity may reflect these ancient practices.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian tennis player, defeated Sam Querrey in straight sets to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, currently ranked 12th in the world, had just won the Japan Open and was feeling tired from his recent success and travel. He attributed his subdued behavior during the match to fatigue and the challenges of traveling to the tournament venue. Kyrgios had previously been fined for a verbal outburst at the same tournament the year before.

The passage discusses a push by scientists and charities for the Welsh government to extend the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination program to boys, in addition to the existing program for girls aged 12 and 13. The HPV jab is known to protect against cervical cancer and is now recognized as a means to prevent head and neck cancers, which are increasingly affecting younger, non-smoking men. Key organizations and experts are urging the Welsh government to act proactively on this public health issue, while the government awaits advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, attended a school prom in his honor before passing away. His mother, Allison, announced his death on Facebook. Jak had been documenting his cancer journey on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which gained over 28,000 likes. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and was supported by his family, girlfriend, and many well-wishers, including football players and celebrities. He received awards for his achievements and overcoming adversity. After learning his cancer had spread, Jak chose to fight and continue living his life to the fullest, inspiring many. His family urged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and a charity football match was planned in his honor.

In a lackluster match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda in the 89th minute when Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said's goal. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt will face Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated. Ghana had already qualified by beating Mali 1-0 earlier. The match was played on a deteriorating pitch, with Egypt struggling to break down Uganda's defense. Uganda had chances but failed to register a shot on target.

Lancashire County Council has selected land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a potential new railway station in Skelmersdale. The decision comes after a study by Network Rail and plans made in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The preferred site is large enough for future expansion, has good highway access, and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without a railway station. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land.
The passage describes the discovery of plants in an "elaborate grow house" within a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the location.

A 28-year-old woman was found severely injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, from nearby Bad Muender, surrendered to authorities. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School, University of Warwick, and University of Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay raise, but are 25% less likely to receive one. The research, based on 4,600 full-time and part-time workers in Australia, debunked the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women avoid asking for more money due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from gender stereotypes. The study suggests that pure discrimination against women may be a factor. Additionally, the study found that men and women under 40 ask for and receive pay raises at similar rates, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior among younger workers.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location due to various issues like site size, ground conditions, or restrictive covenants. The two existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley will be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After these cemeteries are full, the council will only be able to offer family plots, reserved plots, and ash interments. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19 to 22, will offer an augmented reality app for visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews from signs and posters. The festival features acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. The app aims to enhance the festival experience for attendees and allow global interaction, providing real-time updates, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham but collapsed and died shortly after due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse had no significant underlying health issues and that such episodes are rare. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, causing him to overheat and wobble, but he had no such symptoms on the day of his death. He was described by his trainer as the "horse of a lifetime" and had won notable races in the past.

A 34-year-old individual named Davina (formerly known as David Ayrton) was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and identifies as a woman, will be sentenced on March 4 and is currently remanded in a male prison due to potential risks. The victim reported the attack in 2014, and Ayrton's trial involved discussions about her sexuality and the circumstances of the assault. The case was noted for its unusual nature by Judge Ian Pearson.

The passage discusses recent tennis results involving Serbian players. Novak Djokovic, the world number one, lost in the singles to Juan Martin del Potro and earlier lost to Sam Querrey at Wimbledon. Djokovic later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto. Additionally, Serbian players lost a doubles match 6-4 6-4 to Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, with over 20 competitors from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants must use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in September and is close to returning to play. He aims to be fit for the Six Nations tournament starting in February. Webb has renewed his contract with both the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region despite other offers. Wales' first Six Nations match is against Ireland on February 7th.

On Tuesday morning, U.S. border agents near Sumas, Washington, intercepted two men attempting to smuggle 58 pounds of MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Nathan Hall, fled and was later arrested by Canadian police. The other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately taken into custody. Two more individuals, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for their alleged roles in the plot. The group faces conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.
