He was praised for his unique writing style, wit, and intelligence, and was considered the "heart and soul" of the Sunday Times. Gill was known for his controversial yet popular columns, which often sparked outrage. Despite his dyslexia, he had a successful career as a writer, starting with art reviews in the 1980s and later joining the Sunday Times. He was married twice and had four children. Gill's final column, about coming to terms with his diagnosis, was published in the Sunday Times following his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator while performing on stage in a traditional robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol that is traditional in Mongolia but associated with Nazism elsewhere. He was reportedly hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, spending about 10 days in a coma. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, disputing local reports as distorted. The attacker, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested, with authorities stating the injury was not serious. Sukhbaatar's family and lawyer deny reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against an airport's expansion plans on Monday at 03:30 BST on the northern runway. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area and will appear in court on August 19. The Metropolitan Police will review the airport's security.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Match:** Glamorgan vs. Gloucestershire
- **Key Scorer:** Nick Selman (Glamorgan) scored 101 off 144 balls.
- **Key Bowlers:** Matt Taylor and Craig Miles (Gloucestershire) took wickets regularly.
- **Glamorgan's Total:** 220 runs.
- **Gloucestershire's Innings:** Struggled, day ended evenly balanced.
- **Glamorgan Captain:** Michael Hogan (standing in for Jacques Rudolph).
- **Selman's Comments:** Expressed relief at scoring runs after a series of low scores.
- **Taylor's Comments:** Happy with the bowling performance and his personal bowling figures.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police after making threats online to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a false police report to ambush and shoot officers on the Dee Estuary, with threats made twice late at night while he was drunk. Hughes has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail for unrelated firearms offences at the time. He will be sentenced next week and remains in custody. His legal team stated he had no intention of carrying out the threats or harming himself.

**Summary:**

- **Match:** Yorkshire vs. Surrey
- **Score:** Surrey 255-7 (Davies and Foakes shared a 130-run stand)
- **Yorkshire Chase:** All out for 236 (Tim Bresnan scored 68)
- **Key Moments:**
  - Stuart Meaker took 3 wickets in 9 balls for Surrey
  - Yorkshire dropped key catches
  - Yorkshire needed 27 runs off the final 3 overs but fell short
- **Coaches' Comments:**
  - Surrey's Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes' partnership
  - Yorkshire's Alex Lees expressed disappointment, noting they hadn't performed well in crucial moments.

The 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced flooding that its onboard pump couldn't handle. At 07:00 BST, the crew contacted Holyhead coastguards for assistance. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses Scottish runner Laura Muir, who will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine exams in May. The 24-year-old finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir expressed her disappointment but prioritized her degree. She plans to focus on her studies and may target the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir is optimistic about her future in athletics, believing she has at least two or three more Olympics in her.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Liverpool's Title Challenge:** Liverpool is far from repeating last season's title challenge and may struggle to secure a top-four finish. Their fans have high expectations due to last season's overachievement.
- **Transfer Market:** Manager Brendan Rodgers has been criticized for his transfer dealings, particularly in the striker position. The team lacks the goal-scoring and work-rate of last season's top forwards, Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge.
- **Team Performance:** Liverpool has struggled with intensity, pressing, and set-pieces this season. Their defense remains a concern, and they lack a leader at the back.
- **Upcoming Match:** Against Chelsea, Liverpool needs to improve defensively and ensure their full-backs contribute to both defense and attack. However, Chelsea is currently performing at a much higher level.
- **Steven Gerrard:** Despite last season's slip against Chelsea, Gerrard remains a key player for Liverpool. He faces a physical and mental battle to extend his career, but his desire and determination will keep him going.

The passage discusses plans for a Â£45m educational facility in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council proposes to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was known for his novels, including the Laidlaw trilogy, and was titled the "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster, and was passionate about education. McIlvanney passed away on December 5th.

**Concise Summary:**

- A sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was spotted in a river near a town.
- An evacuation and exclusion zones were established, affecting three streets and a half-mile radius at sea.
- Ferry services were disrupted, and residents were advised to stay indoors.
- The mine was moved to a safer location due to its deteriorated condition.
- Authorities stressed that the evacuation was precautionary, and there was no immediate danger.
- Local council thanked residents for their patience during the operation.

**Summary:**

- UK Sport allocated £345 million to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, a slight decrease from the Rio Games.
- Targets for Tokyo: 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals.
- Several sports lost funding, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, badminton, and basketball.
- Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, had its funding removed, while judo's funding increased slightly.
- New sports added for Tokyo 2020 include baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton.
- UK Sport aims to prioritize sports with high medal potential.
- Some sports expressed disappointment, particularly team sports, which feel overlooked.

The passage discusses a planned development in Bournemouth's East Cliff, a designated conservation area. The proposal involves demolishing three Victorian hotels (Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View) to build a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (a nine-storey and a seven-storey building with 122 apartments). Despite objections from English Heritage and some residents citing the loss of historic character, the council voted seven to three in favor, arguing it would boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. The developers, The East Cliff Project LLP, received 246 letters of support.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely, 24, while off-duty in Brecon. Vallely punched and beat Boyd, who was later found unconscious and died. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8. Boyd, from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was in Brecon for training exercises. Vallely, who was drunk and boasting about his strength, dragged Boyd's body away and fled. The community and Boyd's family expressed shock and grief, with Boyd's family describing him as a loving and promising individual.

**Summary:**

- **Incident**: Voters in Barnet were initially turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list.
- **Resignation**: Andrew Travers, the council's chief executive, left his post by mutual agreement following the error.
- **Investigation**: An independent investigation has been launched, with findings to be presented publicly by the end of May.
- **Temporary Replacement**: Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over.
- **Council's Response**: Barnet Council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes. They also questioned the fairness of the election result.
- **Cause**: Mr. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the problems.

Gateshead won a football match against Wrexham with a score of 2-1. Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free-kick, and Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham before halftime. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead in the second half, heading in a cross from Craig Baxter. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's performance in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills noted his team's struggles in the second half of recent games.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, with Norway at the top and Afghanistan and Mozambique at the bottom.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, a venture aiming to provide global broadband coverage using a constellation of satellites. Key points include:

- The initial plan is to launch at least 600 satellites, with a potential expansion to over 2,000.
- The project aims to connect every school globally.
- Airbus is involved in manufacturing the satellites using high-volume, low-cost methods, similar to car and plane production.
- The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida.
- The project requires a significant rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked for launches.
- OneWeb has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking loans for completion.
- The UK Space Agency is involved due to OneWeb's registration in the Channel Islands.
- Debris mitigation is a key concern, with OneWeb committing to de-orbit satellites within two years.
- The manufacturing approach may influence the broader satellite industry, but not all satellites will require such high-volume production.

**Concise Summary:**

- **UK Government's Spending Review**: The UK government's recent spending review is putting "unprecedented pressure" on Scottish public expenditure, according to Mr. Swinney.
- **Funding**: Scottish ministers will have £390m more in spending available next year, rising to £750m with underspend included.
- **Scottish Government's Stance**: The Scottish government argues that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11 due to UK government cuts.
- **Key Priorities**: Mr. Swinney promises to protect schools, hospitals, and the police service from austerity cuts.
- **UK Government's Response**: The UK government's Scotland Office emphasizes the stability of the UK economy and the benefits of remaining in the union.
- **Labour's Criticism**: Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget and criticizes the Scottish government's approach to austerity.

The passage discusses the need for Changing Places toilets, which are larger and have more facilities than standard accessible toilets, to accommodate people with severe disabilities who require carers or hoists. Key points include:

- The lack of these facilities can lead to isolation and stress for disabled individuals and their families.
- Campaigners are pushing for Changing Places toilets to be compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers and cinemas.
- There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but this is insufficient for the estimated quarter of a million people who need them.
- Personal stories highlight the psychological impact and practical difficulties faced due to the lack of these facilities.
- While there are guidelines for Changing Places toilets, they are not compulsory, leading to inconsistencies in their availability.
- Some venues, like Arsenal Football Club, have successfully installed these toilets, benefiting both disabled fans and the general public.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the company imposes excessive rents and high fees on its franchisees. McDonald's maintains that it shares both risks and rewards with its franchisees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and various European unions support the complaint, arguing that McDonald's dominant market position harms franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed valid. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are locked into long contracts and pay above-market rates for leased premises, leading to higher prices and reduced consumer choice compared to company-owned stores. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company earned $9.27 billion from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A 13-year-old boy named Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh was started by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and it went viral. The campaign has received global support, including a mysterious billboard in Holywood and widespread social media engagement. Josh's family and friends, along with people worldwide, are supporting him in his recovery.

The UK is undergoing a military reorganization that includes the closure of historic Brecon Barracks, which has been in operation since 1805. Conservative MP Chris Davies opposes the closure, citing the barracks' historical significance and potential impact on local unemployment and military tourism. The closure is part of a broader restructuring that includes the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and the eventual shutdown of Cawdor Barracks and a storage depot at Sennybridge. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced these changes, while Labour's Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but expressed concern about the impact on local livelihoods.

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. Key points include:

- The UK fishing industry, which contributes 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 people, risks being marginalized in Brexit negotiations.
- The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been unpopular in the UK, and Brexit is seen by some as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters.
- The House of Lords warns that the UK may need to allow EU boats access to UK waters in exchange for continued market access.
- The UK's fishing industry is heavily dependent on exports to the EU and imports from EU states.
- Brexit could lead to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.
- Despite concerns, many in the industry are optimistic about Brexit, seeing it as a chance for better fisheries management and fairer shares in catching opportunities.
- The UK government aims to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade with the EU while reviewing fisheries management post-Brexit.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Source of Leaks**: Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks about US surveillance programs.
- **Surveillance Programs**: The US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, phone records, and social media activity, through programs like PRISM.
- **Data Access**: The NSA can access data from major technology companies, although the extent and methods of this access are debated.
- **Government Stance**: US officials argue that these surveillance programs are necessary for national security and preventing terrorism.
- **International Concerns**: The EU and other entities have expressed concerns about the implications of these programs for privacy and data protection, especially for non-US citizens.
- **Public Reaction**: Privacy advocates and some experts have raised concerns about the potential for abuse and the lack of transparency in these surveillance programs.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Organization**: OpenAI, backed by notable figures and companies like Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services.
- **Mission**: To advance AI for positive human impact, without financial constraints.
- **Concerns**: Some experts, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, warn about potential existential threats from advanced AI.
- **Goals**: To benefit humanity, distribute AI broadly and evenly, and acknowledge both the potential benefits and risks of human-level AI.
- **Funding**: $1 billion pledged, with only a fraction to be spent in the next few years.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch in 2012. Despite a brain injury that temporarily took his speech, he has regained it and maintains his personality and humor. He is an avid gym-goer and fundraiser for military charities. Parkinson received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, exceeding the platform's limit, and has gained significant public support and media attention. His mother, Diane, expressed her son's elation and gratitude for the overwhelming support. Facebook suggested he consider a public page or use the subscribe feature due to his increased public figure status. The Olympic torch relay involved 8,000 people over 70 days.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate was 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, with the poverty threshold for a family of four at $23,021. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%. The percentage of uninsured Americans decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%. The poverty rate had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The passage discusses Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who joined Lancashire (the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013 and has extended his contract until 2019. Buttler is known for his short-format cricket skills, holding the record for England's three fastest One Day International (ODI) centuries. Cricket director Ashley Giles praises Buttler's talent and positive influence on the team, noting his contribution to their T20 Blast final win. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League, is set to return to Lancashire for their upcoming T20 Blast game against Durham.

The passage discusses the decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, which are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bids for these ships were registered by January 23, with no proposals to preserve them submitted so far. Final bids are being prepared, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a decision expected in the spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, hopes at least one ship will be saved, preferably for a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return for the taxpayer. The Type 22 frigates were versatile combatants with strong weapons systems and command facilities, originally designed for anti-submarine warfare.

**Concise Summary:**

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced racial and political tensions leading to several coups and international isolation. Key events include:

- 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians, leading to a series of constitutional changes and economic harm.
- 2000 coup by George Speight, targeting the ethnic Indian prime minister.
- 2006 military takeover, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years.
- 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth due to lack of democratic progress.
- 2014 elections, leading to restored diplomatic ties and Commonwealth reinstatement.

Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing. The economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, but faces persistent trade and budget deficits, relying heavily on aid.

**Summary:**

- Syria is working to destroy its chemical weapons but missed a deadline due to attacks on shipments.
- Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, blamed delays on attacks by terrorist groups and the ongoing war.
- The US and UK have criticized Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, while Syria denies targeting civilians.
- Rebels reportedly seized Aleppo's central prison, freeing detainees, but Syria denies this.
- Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, with only 4% removed so far.
- Russia and the OPCW have set deadlines for the removal and destruction of Syria's chemical weapons.
- Syria insists it is committed to its agreements and will meet its obligations.

The passage discusses the 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, which includes six authors: Jhumpa Lahiri (The Lives of Others), Howard Jacobson (J), Ali Smith (How To Be Both), Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), and Richard Flanagan (The Narrow Road to the Deep North). The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall. Fowler's book is the best-selling among the shortlisted novels. The Booker Prize is in its 46th year, and the shortlisted authors each receive £2,500. The ceremony will be covered by the BBC.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his name being published in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will decide whether to grant the appeal and, if so, whether to allow or dismiss it. An interim injunction remains in place until the end of the hearing. PJS is trying to prevent the publication of an account of his alleged extra-marital activities by The Sun on Sunday, arguing for his right to privacy. The Court of Appeal ruled that the details of the allegations are now so widespread that confidentiality has likely been lost, making it difficult to enforce the injunction.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was recently purchased for £345.5m. The new owners plan to address parking and traffic congestion issues, as well as improve the appearance of the units and common areas. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, and Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, have discussed these improvements, aiming to enhance the visual appeal and functionality of the park, which serves as a gateway from Blaby into the city.

The live-action film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. Initially delayed for review, the Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, granting it a "P13" rating. The film's release date remains unannounced, and local cinemas are offering refunds. The decision to review the film was criticized by netizens.

**Summary:**

- Landlords in Southampton must license Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) for properties with more than three unrelated tenants, but many avoid this due to the £1,000 cost, despite facing up to £20,000 in fines.
- The council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area.
- Tenants often face eviction fears and poor maintenance.
- Mandatory licensing nationally applies to three-storey or more houses with five or more unrelated people.
- In Southampton, specific areas require licenses: Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (since 2013), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (since 2015).
- The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

After an inconclusive election, Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are trying to avoid another election by forming a minority government. The main obstacle is the water charges issue, with Fianna Fáil wanting them removed immediately and Fine Gael wanting to keep them. Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party has enough seats to form a majority government. A commission to review Irish Water is one of the proposals being considered.

The ferry Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck about 27km from Mallorca. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and later transferred to the ferry Puglia. At least three people were injured, one seriously. The ship may sink, and the rescued passengers are heading back to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists are being sent to provide counseling. The fire's cause is unknown.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs had received claims of people, including students, voting twice, which is a criminal offense. The commission suggested better integration of individual electoral registers managed by councils to identify duplicate entries. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June 8 election, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in voter registration applications, totaling 2.9 million over six weeks. However, concerns persist about duplicate applications due to unlinked electoral registers and online registration systems. The commission estimates that 30% to 70% of applications in different areas were duplicates, causing administrative and financial burdens. They recommend clearer information and verification functions on registration sites. Labour warned against making it harder for young people and students to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL star who played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, was found dead in his cell on Wednesday. He was 40. Phillips had a troubled history both on and off the field, leading to multiple legal issues and a prison sentence of over 30 years. He was recently accused of killing his former cellmate and was awaiting trial. His former coach, Tom Osborne, noted that Phillips had intelligence and good qualities but struggled with anger issues and personal demons. The cause of his death is unknown.

Private Derby XXX, a ram and official soldier of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behavior. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to 1858. Derby XXX joined the regiment in 2014, has an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays for mating. He has participated in public events, including switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

**Concise Summary:**

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, advancing to the last four. The match was marked by intense emotion, excitement, and a remarkable comeback led by manager Jürgen Klopp. Liverpool, initially trailing 3-0, scored four unanswered goals in the second half, with Dejan Lovren's injury-time header sealing the win. Klopp's inspirational leadership and the fans' unwavering belief were pivotal in the turnaround. The victory highlighted Liverpool's resilience and growing confidence under Klopp, who has instilled his philosophy in the team and fans. The win also brings them a step closer to qualifying for the Champions League.

**Concise Summary:**

Following a meeting in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis and Scottish Constitutional Relations Secretary Michael Russell discussed the UK's EU negotiations. Key points include:

- Davis committed to monthly meetings and a "two-way information flow" with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to share analysis and gather views.
- Russell called for more transparency from the UK government about its Brexit plans and stressed the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economy.
- The UK government and Scottish government have differing views on the Brexit process and may oppose each other in the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50.

The passage discusses a study on cloned sheep, including four that are genetic twins of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr and Professor Kevin Sinclair of the University of Nottingham are conducting physical examinations and tests on these sheep to determine if they age normally and are healthy. The concern is that the cloning process might transfer "age-memory" from the donor cell, causing the clones to age prematurely. Dolly had died at six-and-a-half years old with osteoarthritis, raising concerns about premature aging. The study focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis in the cloned sheep. The results, which could impact the future of cloning, are set to be published soon. Currently, the cloned sheep, approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear healthy.

The passage discusses several horse races and the decisions made by trainers John Gosden and William Haggas:

1. **Unbeaten Favorite**: An unnamed unbeaten favorite, trained by John Gosden, won a race and will next compete in Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom. Stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks.

2. **Duke of York Stakes**: Tasleet, trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, won the Duke of York Stakes, finishing ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas.

3. **Musidora Stakes**: Shutter Speed, trained by Gosden and ridden by Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes. Despite the soft ground, Dettori praised Shutter Speed's performance and class. She will next compete in the French Oaks at Chantilly.

4. **Dante Stakes**: Trainer John Gosden is considering whether to run his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes due to concerns about the ground conditions. The short turnaround between the Dante Stakes and the Derby may also influence this decision.

The passage discusses the volatility of the British pound and financial markets due to the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit referendum. Key points include:

- The pound fluctuated against the dollar, euro, and yen, with a general downward trend.
- The "volatility index" reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis.
- Polls and betting odds indicated a narrowing gap between the Leave and Remain campaigns, increasing market uncertainty.
- Financial analysts and traders noted heightened volatility and "twitchy" market activity.
- Asian stock markets and the FTSE 100 experienced declines due to Brexit concerns.
- Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters.

The passage discusses the current standings and recent performance of two football teams, Braintree Town (referred to as "The Iron") and Barrow. Braintree is sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. They recently lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten streak to nine games. Despite the loss, Braintree manager Cowley remains optimistic about their journey, acknowledging the challenges ahead as a part-time team.

**Concise Summary:**

From April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will take over most planning decisions, shifting responsibility from the Planning Service. This change aims to democratize the planning system, allowing councils to accept or reject developments in their areas. While some, like Michael Corr from PLACE, see this as an opportunity for local development, others, such as Friends of the Earth, express concerns about potential discrimination, lack of transparency, and the influence of developers. There are also debates about the disclosure of political donations in relation to this new power. The Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to implement stricter donation disclosure rules.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured in Winchburgh, Scotland, after being shot three times with an airgun. She was shot twice in the shoulder and once in her left back leg, which had to be amputated. Teenie's owner, Sarah Nisbett, expressed concern about the incident, given the presence of children in the housing estate. The Scottish SPCA and Teenie's owners are seeking the person responsible. The incident has reignited calls for airgun licensing in Scotland, despite a previous consultation where 87% of respondents opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA urged anyone with information to come forward.

Christian Benteke joined Liverpool as their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. The 24-year-old Belgian international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, was acquired by triggering a release clause in his contract. Liverpool, aiming to revive their attack after struggling for goals last season, also signed forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Benteke, known for his goal-scoring ability and physical presence, is expected to handle the pressure and contribute significantly to Liverpool's forward line. Former managers and players have expressed optimism about his potential impact at Anfield.

The passage discusses a study on the use of tablet devices in schools, commissioned by Tablets for Schools. Key points include:

- Tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with academy schools showing the highest usage.
- There is no clear evidence that tablets improve academic results, but head teachers report positive impacts and increased motivation among pupils.
- Tablets are increasingly common in schools, with their number expected to rise from 430,000 to 900,000 between 2014 and 2016.
- A separate study suggests touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read.
- Many pupils use tablets for social media and entertainment, with some reporting internet "addiction."
- Head teachers like Simon Mason advocate for tablets, citing benefits such as empowerment, trust, and alignment with modern life and work.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs depicting the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition showcases both the joys and hardships of childhood, including play, special occasions, and child labor. Notable images include a portrait from 1887 of the Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball and a photograph of a young maid from around 1900. The exhibition runs until September 25.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Players:**
  - **Myles Anderson** (27, centre-back): Left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival. Previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Could play against his former club on February 18.
  - **Ruairi Keating** (21, striker): Recommended to Torquay United (the Gulls) boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams. Previously played for Irish clubs Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is subject to international clearance.

- **Team Situation:**
  - Torquay United is four points above the relegation zone and has won only one of their last six games.

- **Manager's Quotes:**
  - Nicholson on Anderson: "He is the stature, the voice, and is the leader-type I've been after."
  - Nicholson on Keating: "He is young, a little bit raw, but incredibly hungry to show what he's about."

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. Key points include:

- The law aims to address Bolivia's poverty and sets harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide.
- Over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work, often in challenging conditions.
- The law was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in President Evo Morales's absence.
- The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is reviewing the law to determine if it violates international child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old woman, Rosie O'Donnell, experienced a severe heart attack, known as the "widow maker," after feeling chest pain, nausea, and fever. She researched her symptoms online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a nearly blocked artery. O'Donnell did not call emergency services but warned others to recognize symptoms and seek help immediately. She is known for her acting roles in various films and TV shows, and recently hosted a talk show that was canceled due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed and killed in an alleyway in Kenton, London, after a party on Saturday night. He was not involved in an initial altercation but was targeted later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police have arrested three individuals in connection with the incident: a 21-year-old man on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 on suspicion of murder (both bailed until mid-December), and a 14-year-old boy on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. Police are seeking witnesses from the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate.

**Concise Summary:**

Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis process to address poor survival statistics and long waiting times, especially for non-obvious cancer cases. They introduced a three-route model:

1. **Fast-track routes** for patients with alarming cancer symptoms.
2. **Diagnosis centers** for patients with undiagnosed symptoms for quick tests and scans.
3. **"Yes-no" centers** for patients with minor symptoms to rule out serious diseases quickly.

The changes have improved survival rates and better organized patient diagnosis within existing resources. A team from Wales visited Denmark to learn from these changes, as both countries have similar health systems.

A new system will allow for warnings and bans against dishonest or law-breaking estate agents, replacing the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). Powys County Council won the bid to handle this service, receiving £170,000 annually. Complaints will still go to local trading standards, who will refer relevant cases to Powys. James Munro of Powys Council will lead the team and hopes this role will open doors to more contracts.

The passage discusses a plan approved by NHS Employers to reshape the NHS workforce, based on a Nuffield Trust review. Key points include:

- Nurses and pharmacists are already filling in for doctors due to staffing gaps.
- The plan aims to address shortages of junior doctors and GPs, who are struggling with increased patient numbers.
- The Nuffield Trust suggests leveraging the 1.3 million-strong workforce to cover doctor shortages and manage long-term conditions.
- While the plan offers opportunities for improved patient care and staff roles, it requires funding for training.
- Unions and the British Medical Association warn against using the plan as a quick fix and emphasize the importance of proper training and staff support for doctors.

**Summary:**

- **Duration of Closure:** 03:00 GMT to 14:00 GMT.
- **Impact:** Disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour.
- **Current Status:** Investigations are ongoing. Some bus services have resumed, with full service expected by the evening commute.
- **Response:** First Bus managing director James Freeman thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) over the environmental impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimates that the lagoon could cause a 21% mortality rate for salmon and 25% for sea trout annually, while TLP argues that the figures lack scientific basis and claim their own modeling shows a worst-case scenario of 2% mortality for all fish species. TLP also criticizes NRW for not sharing its methodology. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, and the Welsh Government supports the scheme but seeks clarity from the UK government. NRW defends its evidence and methodology, asserting it has been thoroughly assessed by experts.

**Summary:**

- Northern Ireland's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister, Arlene Foster, announced the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body.
- The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland is significant, employing nearly 100,000 people across various sectors.
- The new body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and coordination for marketing activities in the sector.
- Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting the industry's importance for export-led economic growth, but also raised potential implications for other organizations.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood, Faughan Valley, on Saturday afternoon. This is part of a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees to honor those who died in WW1. At Brackfield Wood, the goal is to plant 40,000 trees, commemorating the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The charity invites local people and visitors to participate, with the director encouraging many to join and plant a tree. By the project's end, Brackfield Wood will feature 40,000 native trees and wildflowers, creating a space for wildlife and reflection. The event is about seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence and honor crime, featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The book was praised for its emotional power, tight writing, and atmospheric storytelling. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her work on the VI Warshawski series, which was noted for its strong female protagonist and impact on crime fiction. The awards were presented at the start of the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate, with Ann Cleeves serving as the festival programming chair.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was killed in a hit-and-run incident on a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, ruled it an unlawful killing, suggesting it was a staged hit-and-run. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger, is suspected of involvement. She attempted to claim his assets shortly after his death and was reportedly having an affair. The Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011. The case remains active but is not actively pursued.

Charlie, from Merseyside, needs to travel to Seattle for experimental T-Cell Therapy, which is not available in the UK. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed gratitude to an anonymous donor who paid for the treatment after Charlie's last transplant failed. Charlie has been ill since age three and had no other treatment options in the UK after a third relapse in April. The family was overwhelmed by the generous donation and expects to start the treatment soon, with the date to be confirmed next week.

Apple has implemented a two-step verification process for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access, following reports of celebrity photo hacks. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after logging in with their username and password. The feature is opt-in, but experts suggest it should be the default. Apple's change blocks tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which was previously used to access iCloud data. The update also notifies users when a backup is downloaded. However, there are concerns about the recovery key's complexity and potential loss. Apple plans to encourage users to adopt two-factor authentication and stronger passwords.

A potential deal is being discussed where Wright could buy 20% of Billericay, a club currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright, known for being the runner-up in "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, has a history of playing non-league football. The club was recently acquired by Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been asked to provide evidence regarding his company's treatment of workers, following a BBC investigation into the Derbyshire company's warehouse practices. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee has invited Mr. Ashley to a public meeting at Westminster to discuss the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. If Mr. Ashley does not agree to attend, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not yet responded to the BBC's request for comment, but has previously agreed to review worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," completed by colleagues of a murdered Russian opposition politician, Boris Nemtsov. The report compiles existing media facts to accuse President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. Key points include:

- Russia's denial of sending regular troops to Ukraine, contrasted with claims by Ilya Yashin that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in rebel victories.
- Evidence of Russian generals directing battles and volunteers being paid to fight.
- Estimated Russian spending on the conflict and difficulties in publishing and distributing the report.
- The opposition's view that Putin directed the war to boost his popularity, while some Russians support Moscow's involvement in Ukraine.
- The report's potential limited impact, similar to Nemtsov's previous works on corruption and the Sochi Olympics.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, died from head injuries. Two individuals, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman, were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are in custody.

The passage discusses a disagreement between the Welsh government and the UK government regarding the Brexit process. Key points include:

- Jones criticized the UK government for lacking respect towards the devolved administrations.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was removed from his position last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. The company's board stated they do not expect him to return. Charney's lawyer denies many of the accusations, claiming the company invaded his privacy and attempted to extort him. The company alleges Charney violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, making it unlikely for any board to hire him again. Recently, the company obtained a restraining order to prevent Charney from making negative statements about them or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30 to 19:30 BST. The game is a rematch, with Greece having won the previous encounter in Patras, Greece, earlier this month. Three Greek players from that game will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box in Stratford. This game is GB's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in Istanbul, Turkey, in early September. Following this match, GB will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final warm-up before EuroBasket.

The passage discusses the launch of the iPhone and its transformative impact on technology and society. The author recounts how they secured one of the first public views of the iPhone for a news segment, despite initial difficulties. The iPhone is highlighted as a revolutionary device that put powerful computers in the hands of billions, disrupting various industries and changing how people engage in activities like photography. The author reflects on the iPhone's significance, comparing it to the Model T Ford, and acknowledges the genius of Steve Jobs in creating an attractive user interface. The passage concludes by noting the ongoing innovations by companies like Amazon and Google, but emphasizes that the mobile connected era began with the iPhone's launch.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to the TV show EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to reunite with his on-screen family, the Mitchells, for his mother Peggy's final episodes. Dame Barbara Windsor, who plays Peggy, announced her character's impending death from cancer. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and briefly in 2005-2006, will join Steve McFadden, who plays Phil Mitchell, to film emotional scenes set to air in the spring. The storyline aims to bring together key characters and create memorable episodes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when informed of her death by police. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's parents, feeling guilt for not taking the threat more seriously, established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking.

The passage discusses the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project in Somerset, which is primarily funded by the French firm EDF and Chinese investors. Key points include:

- EDF's board approved the funding, but the UK government has not yet given its final backing.
- The project has faced criticism over potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign involvement.
- The UK government launched a further review of the project hours after EDF's approval, causing uncertainty.
- Hinkley Point C is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity and has faced financial concerns and resignations from EDF executives.
- Environmentalists and industry groups have expressed concerns and urged the government to make a swift decision.
- The project has a history of delays and uncertainties, with the latest setback being the UK government's postponement of a final decision.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom a spouse allegedly committed adultery, which family lawyers warn may increase conflict. The Ministry of Justice states that naming this person is not obligatory. The form aims to simplify the legal process, even for those without legal advice. However, lawyers express concern that people might fill in the name due to the form's design, despite guidance suggesting it's not necessary. Naming the third party can complicate the case and delay proceedings. In 2015, adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces out of over 100,000 granted. Most clients want to involve the new partner, but judges frown upon this. To apply for a divorce, one must prove the marriage has broken down and provide a reason.

The passage discusses a debate in Wales over forestry policy. Key points include:

- Britain is the world's third largest wood importer, and Wales has significant timber industry, worth over £450m annually.
- There's a conflict between promoting commercial forestry (mainly conifers) and environmental policies favoring native broadleaf species and public access.
- Since 2001, Wales has lost 16,000 hectares of commercial forest, and more needs to be replanted.
- The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects of forestry, encouraging woodland creation through schemes like Glastir.
- Industry representatives argue that bureaucratic processes and a focus on environmental aspects hinder the growth of commercial forestry.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge. The incident occurred near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street around 16:40. Emergency services transported him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported as serious.

The passage discusses the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Russia. Key points include:

- The Arctic Convoys were missions during World War II where vessels traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union, facing severe conditions and German attacks.
- Over 3,000 Allied seamen lost their lives, and by May 1945, 120 vessels were lost.
- The British government initially blocked the awarding of the Ushakov medal due to rules on foreign medals, but later allowed an exception.
- Veteran Charles Lewis, 91, expressed honor and delight in receiving the medal, acknowledging the convoys' significance but not considering himself a hero.
- The Russian Embassy emphasized the importance of the convoys in their wartime alliance and the recognition of the veterans' contributions.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant issues with the implementation of community payback (unpaid work) sentences in the UK. Key problems included delays in starting work, offenders not attending, and inadequate enforcement. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work, but the system faced organizational challenges, particularly with offenders who lead chaotic lives. The inspectors praised some high-quality work and positive offender experiences but noted that unpaid work was often seen merely as punishment. The report made 15 recommendations for improvement, which the Ministry of Justice agreed to implement. The ministry emphasized the need for better rehabilitation and enforcement of court-ordered work.

The passage discusses a comedian who is often accused of hypocrisy for advocating for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. The comedian, Russell Brand, has been criticized by a newspaper for this perceived contradiction. Brand has addressed these accusations in the past, acknowledging his wealth and fame but arguing that he is aware of the need for personal and systemic change. He has also expressed frustration with the focus on his personal wealth rather than the broader issues of economic disparity and ecological disaster. Brand has not responded to inquiries about potential legal action against the newspaper that accused him of hypocrisy.

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for his significant contributions to human genomics and synthetic biology. He accelerated the human genome mapping process, which was controversial due to his competitive approach and disregard for scientific conventions. Venter's work led to the creation of a synthetic life form called Synthia, published in the journal Science. Born in 1946, Venter's experiences in Vietnam inspired him to pursue medicine and research. He developed innovative methods for gene sequencing, which initially faced criticism but ultimately sped up the field. Venter founded several research institutes and companies, including Celera Genomics, which competed with public efforts to sequence the human genome. His work on synthetic life and oceanic genetic treasure hunts continues to push scientific boundaries, albeit with controversy.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that school lunches expose children to new foods, with 80% of children trying something new at school that they hadn't at home. Half of the parents reported that their children asked for school-tried foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among schoolchildren were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less favored. The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, aimed to address concerns from parents who believed their children were too picky to eat school meals. Both the School Food Trust and Mumsnet highlighted the potential of school meals to encourage children to try new foods and eat more varied diets. School meals in England must adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary school children and slightly fewer secondary school children eating them. In Scotland, approximately 46% of children eat school lunches. The survey was conducted online from February 26 to March 5 among parents with children aged 4-17.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish footballer, plays for Juventus and Spain. He joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, with a buy-back option for Real at up to 30 million euros. Morata has scored three goals for Spain at Euro 2016, 27 goals in two seasons for Juventus, and 10 goals for Real Madrid. He has won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias with Juventus, and played in two consecutive Champions League finals.

Wilson rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 and was released in May. He made 51 appearances during his second spell at Nottingham Forest, having previously played there for four seasons. Before his time at Celtic and Nottingham Forest, Wilson also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa Companies. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, and Tesco will loan it approximately £80 million. Fresh & Easy, which has 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its inception in 2007. Tesco will close 50 of these stores and incur a total cost of £150 million to dispose of the brand. Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm led by Ron Burkle, may allow Tesco to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable. This sale follows Tesco's first annual profit decline in 20 years, reported in April.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it. He considered representing France but is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, there is a mention of a guide on how to get into martial arts.

The passage discusses the retreat of glaciers in the French Alps from the late 1960s/early 1970s to the late 2000s. Key points include:

- Glacier area decreased from 375 sq km to 275 sq km, an average loss of 26% over 40 years.
- The retreat is more pronounced in the southern sectors, with significant losses in the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs.
- The northern Alps, including the Mont Blanc Massif, have seen less retreat due to higher elevation and different climatic conditions.
- The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting and was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie.
- The study used map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to assess the glaciers, with manual inspection to verify automatic delineation methods.

The Scottish women's national football team has won all five of their qualifiers and is set to host Iceland, aiming to secure their place in the finals. Key player Erin Evans expresses the importance of not missing out again after previous play-off losses. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, and the outcome of their matches will likely decide the group's top spot. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically for the finals in the Netherlands. Evans highlights the benefits of having players in top leagues abroad, noting the competitive edge it brings to the national team. The match against Iceland is anticipated to be crucial and emotionally charged.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following allegations of harassment made by a woman in south London. The harassment is alleged to have occurred over a two-year period via tweets, which Campbell insists were not threatening. Campbell was released on bail until mid-September. He has accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation about the case.

PETA proposes replacing the Skegness mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to promote animal-friendliness. Peta argues that the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomes suggestions but believes the Jolly Fisherman is well-loved and does not portray animal cruelty. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 to promote seaside breaks in Skegness.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from the U.S. detention facility in Guantanamo, Cuba, after a review panel determined he was not a significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. Odah's release came after the Kuwaiti government advocated for it, and he will spend at least a year in a rehabilitation center in Kuwait. He is the first detainee to be freed since May 2014. His release reduces the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility was opened in 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has vowed to close it.

Anzac Day commemorations were held in London, marking the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One. Thousands attended a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade, and a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Services were also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day service in the capital was held in 1916, attended by King George V. The day honors the sacrifices of New Zealanders and Australians in all wars, with veterans, service personnel, and their families participating in the events. The Gallipoli campaign, commemorated on Anzac Day, was one of the bloodiest of World War One.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. There were initial concerns about the future of the workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements, including the existing pension arrangements, would be honored under the new ownership. The final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and members currently have an alternative pension scheme that remains unaffected by the takeover. Boparan plans to invest in the business, achieve cost savings, and utilize spare capacity to process both chicken and turkeys to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability.

The passage discusses issues with a new ferry service at Cowes. Key points include:

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. Key points include:

- The UK fishing industry, which makes up only 0.5% of GDP and employs 12,000 people, risks being marginalized in Brexit negotiations.
- The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been unpopular in the UK, and Brexit is seen as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters.
- The UK may need to allow EU boats to fish in its waters in exchange for market access.
- The industry's success depends on continued market access, likely involving trade-offs.
- Brexit could lead to four different fisheries management regimes in the UK.
- Despite concerns, many in the industry are optimistic about Brexit, seeing it as a chance for better fisheries management and control over UK waters.
- The government aims to balance trade with the EU and improved fisheries management post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney admitted to possessing and permitting the creation of inappropriate images of young boys between 2004 and 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and required to participate in a program for sex offenders. Due to the nature of his offense, which involved condoning and participating in the abuse of children, the General Teaching Council Scotland found his conduct incompatible with teaching. The panel determined that his behavior was not an isolated incident but a pattern, and there was a strong likelihood of recurrence. Consequently, Geaney was removed from the teaching register and prohibited from re-registering for two years.

- The Environment Agency suspended the firm from accepting waste and later revoked its environmental permit, effective 7 August, unless appealed.
- Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the past year and had raised concerns about potential fire impacts.
- The cause of the fire is still undetermined.
- The company must remove all waste from the site.

**Summary:**

- Syria is working to destroy its chemical weapons but missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile due to attacks on shipments.
- Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% removed so far.
- Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad insists Syria is committed to its agreements and obligations.
- The US and Russia have expressed concerns about the slow progress.
- Meanwhile, intense fighting continues in Aleppo, with reports of barrel bomb attacks and a rebel assault on a central prison.

England won the second Test against Pakistan with a day to spare at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, securing their second-biggest run win over Pakistan. Joe Root was named man of the match for his performances, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. England's captain Alastair Cook and coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root's improved form and responsibility at number three. Pakistan struggled, batting for only 133 overs across both innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far. The third Test is scheduled to begin on August 3 at Edgbaston.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering experiences from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care experiences. The Care Forum Wales supports the review but notes the absence of a care provider expert on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. He previously served as player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, leading them to their first national trophy and promotion in 2011. Sheerin has experience playing for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and he won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser confirmed that Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison supported Sheerin's move to Aberdeen.

**Summary:**

- **Current Situation**: Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's next match after Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea are looking to appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as their first choice.
- **Team's Struggle**: The team is fighting to avoid relegation, with the Championship now seen as a strong league.
- **Club History**: Swansea were promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy. They were known for their exciting, possession-based football.
- **Current Issues**: Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent management changes and failure to adequately replace key players.
- **Relegation Concerns**: Curtis acknowledges that if Swansea go down, it will be tough to get back up, unlike bigger clubs like Newcastle.

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for his significant contributions to human genomics. He turned the human genome mapping effort into a competitive race, which was controversial but sped up the process. Venter's work includes creating a synthetic life form named Synthia, and he has been involved in various ambitious projects, such as sequencing microbial genomes from the oceans. Despite criticism from the scientific community, his efforts have been financially rewarding, allowing him to pursue his research independently. Venter's journey includes a transformation from a surfing enthusiast to a driven scientist inspired by his experiences in the Vietnam War.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low-quality, too short, and not widely offered by employers. Only a small fraction are at the level of A-levels, and most are taken by those over 25. The report contrasts this with Germany's vocational system, which is more extensive and highly regarded. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with a focus on higher-level courses, to boost the economy and improve young people's job prospects. The Department for Education acknowledges reforms are underway, while the Association of Colleges notes the challenges and some strengths of the current system.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of the runner-up. She has 22 Paralympic medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) in cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. Storey, who is 37, started her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and switched to cycling in 2005. She has 21 world titles and is aiming for more success at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Paralympics.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference Premier due to financial issues and failure to pay football creditors. Despite multiple deadline extensions, the club, recently taken over by Tommy Agombar, could not meet the payment requirements. The club's debts amounted to approximately £225,000, with over £70,000 owed to HMRC. Chester FC has taken Hereford's place in the Conference Premier. The club's financial troubles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, with falling attendance exacerbating the situation. An offer by the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club was not accepted.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football for England. He earned 61 caps, debuting in 2009, and was part of two World Cups and two European Championships squads. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, starting in 2004. He scored one international goal, in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in 2014 World Cup qualifiers. He cited common sense as the reason for his decision.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a several-month illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's notable recordings include a 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various academic and artistic directorship positions. Hogwood was praised for his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music. His funeral was private, with a memorial service planned for later.

A boy from Northern Ireland has been unable to attend school due to his special needs. His family has been waiting for a place in a special school since June, but all schools in their area are full. The boy's mother expressed concern about his isolation and the system's capacity to handle other families in similar situations. The Education Authority is reviewing special school provision but could not comment on the specific case due to privacy concerns. The family hopes the boy will start at a local special school in the next few weeks due to a newly employed classroom assistant.

The Newport County football club is currently leasing Rodney Parade stadium until 2023, with priority use if they remain in the Football League. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over the stadium, which is also home to the Newport Gwent Dragons rugby team and Newport Squash Club. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. Newport County is currently fighting to avoid relegation from League Two. The WRU's takeover bid will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on May 9. Newport County chairman, Foxall, expects their lease to be honored and expresses concern about the potential impact of relegation on the club and the city.

The passage discusses the experiences of an individual from Sierra Leone who was kidnapped by rebels at age 15 and forced to fight in a civil war. He endured horrific conditions, including drug use and witnessing atrocities. After escaping, he found support from a preacher who helped him turn his life around. Later, during the Ebola crisis in 2014, he and his team educated communities, provided support, and established an Ebola treatment unit, saving many lives. He now focuses on investing in young people to build a better future. The passage also mentions the total deaths from Ebola in West Africa, with Sierra Leone reporting 3,955 deaths.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of about 80,000 artworks and historical items, which was at risk of being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, has been saved. A public fundraising campaign, led by the Art Fund, successfully raised the necessary funds in a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be loaned from the Victoria and Albert Museum. The collection's sale was finalized on Monday, with administrators praising the goodwill and determination shown during negotiations. The Wedgwood Museum had inherited the pension bill after the firm's collapse in 2009 and had faced the threat of its collection being sold and scattered globally.

A potential deal is being discussed where Danny Wright could buy 20% of Billericay, a club currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright, known for his non-league football career and his appearance on "I'm A Celebrity," could also become a club director. The club was recently acquired by Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 weekly. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool in the 12th minute, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester from a corner in the 17th minute. Notable incidents included several saves by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe, a missed opportunity by Blackpool's Tom Aldred, and Colchester finishing the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle.

The passage discusses plans to repurpose the decommissioned Fawley Power Station, which operated from 1971 to 2013, into a major attraction. The developers, Fawley Waterside, aim to convert the power station's 198-meter-high chimney into the centerpiece of a £1 billion "merchant city" development. This project will include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, capable of powering one million homes, was sold to the developers in 2016, and planning permission is expected to be applied for later in the year, with construction potentially starting in 2018. The chimney is seen as a key feature that can be repurposed with relatively little investment.

**Concise Summary:**

At the Hong Kong championships, British cyclist Ethan Latham won bronze in the men's scratch race, while the men's team pursuit squad missed out on a medal, finishing fourth. Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, and the women's team pursuit squad finished fifth in the heats. Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker, part of the women's team pursuit squad, remained positive about their progress. Additionally, Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint but will compete in two more events.

Ross Kemp is returning to the British soap opera "EastEnders" for a brief role to reunite his character, Grant Mitchell, with his on-screen family, particularly his mother Peggy, who is set to die from cancer. Kemp's return comes after Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, made a surprise appearance to reveal her cancer had returned. The emotional scenes will air in the spring. Kemp played Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and briefly in 2005 and 2006. The storyline will bring together the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil, to deal with their mother's impending death.

In a Premier League match, Sadio Mane scored two goals within 138 seconds for Liverpool against Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs), who are currently in second place. Spurs' manager, Mauricio Pochettino, criticized his team's lack of desire and effort, noting that their poor away performances make it difficult for them to challenge for the Premier League title. Chelsea has the opportunity to increase their lead at the top if they win their next match. Spurs have struggled away from home, winning only twice since September and having a poor record against top-six teams on the road. Former player Danny Murphy also commented on Spurs' poor defensive performance and inconsistent tactics away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost the presidential poll last month and key states. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP retained control of eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, but lost key northern states and failed to secure any of the five oil-producing states. The elections were generally more peaceful but still saw violence in some areas. The PDP's decline is attributed to voter desire for change, defections, and corruption allegations.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) is happening in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19 to 22. This year, the festival offers an augmented reality app to enhance the visitor experience and allow global interaction. The app provides online information, videos, and band interviews accessible via signs and posters on-site. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app also enables ticket purchases and real-time updates about the festival.

Several Birmingham academies, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, have been rated inadequate by Ofsted and face potential termination of their funding agreements. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. A head teacher from one of the affected schools, known as the "Trojan Horse" schools, reported facing challenges from parents and considering quitting. The Department for Education has sent letters outlining concerns and demands for improvements, with deadlines set for responses. Ofsted's chief, Sir Michael Wilshaw, noted a "culture of fear and intimidation" in these schools. Some parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and pushing personal agendas.

Vincent "Vinnie" Barker died in July 2012, five months after an eye test.
